‘It’s the most empathetic voice in my life’: How AI is transforming the lives of neurodivergent people@Reuters7/26/2025

AI tools like ChatGPT are helping neurodivergent users communicate more clearly and confidently — though some experts warn that overreliance could come at a cost.

class="article-body-module__container__oOFyv over-6-para"><div class="article-body-module__content__bnXL1"><div data-testid="PremiumArticleImage" class="premium-article-image-module__container__jOgXE src="https://www.reuters.com/resizer/v2/AILDGXEPLZHSDDFXQIV75A4KLA.jpg?auth=6608b87b8e5b9d604ef1c1eed3589deaf70f811536c1a26ed5cebeece11723f0&width=1920&quality=80" width="1920" height="1280" alt="Neurodivergent illustration" /></noscript></div><div data-testid="Body" class="text-module__text__0GDob text-module__dark-grey__UFC18 text-module__regular__qJJtA text-module__ultra_small__6-vhY body-module__full_width__kCIGb body-module__ultra_small_body__WelUC article-image-module__figcaption__S3axy article-body-module__figcaption__x2MkY premium-article-image-module__figcaption__FwQ0-"><span>Illustration by Karolis Strautniekas</span></div></figure></div><div data-testid="paragraph-0" class="text-module__text__0GDob text-module__dark-grey__UFC18 text-module__regular__qJJtA text-module__small__sph8i body-module__full_width__kCIGb body-module__small_body__gOmDf article-body-module__paragraph__Ts-yF">For Cape Town-based filmmaker Kate D’hotman, connecting with movie audiences comes naturally. Far more daunting is speaking with others. “I’ve never understood how people [decipher] social cues,” the 40-year-old director of horror films says.</div><div data-testid="paragraph-1" class="text-module__text__0GDob text-module__dark-grey__UFC18 text-module__regular__qJJtA text-module__small__sph8i body-module__full_width__kCIGb body-module__small_body__gOmDf article-body-module__paragraph__Ts-yF">D’hotman has autism and attention-deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD), which can make relating to others exhausting and a challenge. However, since 2022, D’hotman has been a regular user of ChatGPT, the popular AI-powered chatbot from OpenAI, relying on it to overcome communication barriers at work and in her personal life. </div><div data-testid="paragraph-2" class="text-module__text__0GDob text-module__dark-grey__UFC18 text-module__regular__qJJtA text-module__small__sph8i body-module__full_width__kCIGb body-module__small_body__gOmDf article-body-module__paragraph__Ts-yF">“I know it’s a machine,” she says. “But sometimes, honestly, it’s the most empathetic voice in my life.” </div><div data-testid="paragraph-3" class="text-module__text__0GDob text-module__dark-grey__UFC18 text-module__regular__qJJtA text-module__small__sph8i body-module__full_width__kCIGb body-module__small_body__gOmDf article-body-module__paragraph__Ts-yF">Neurodivergent people — including those with autism, ADHD, dyslexia and other conditions — can experience the world differently from the neurotypical norm. Talking to a colleague, or even texting a friend, can entail misread signals, a misunderstood tone and unintended impressions.</div><div data-testid="element" class="article-body-module__element__5eCce article-body-module__full_bleed__rXIWT"></div><div data-testid="paragraph-4" class="text-module__text__0GDob text-module__dark-grey__UFC18 text-module__regular__qJJtA text-module__small__sph8i body-module__full_width__kCIGb body-module__small_body__gOmDf article-body-module__paragraph__Ts-yF">AI-powered chatbots have emerged as an unlikely ally, helping people navigate social encounters with real-time guidance. Although this new technology is not without risks — in particular some worry about over-reliance — many neurodivergent users now see it as a lifeline.</div><div data-testid="paragraph-5" class="text-module__text__0GDob text-module__dark-grey__UFC18 text-module__regular__qJJtA text-module__small__sph8i body-module__full_width__kCIGb body-module__small_body__gOmDf article-body-module__paragraph__Ts-yF">How does it work in practice? For D’hotman, ChatGPT acts as an editor, translator and confidant. Before using the technology, she says communicating in neurotypical spaces was difficult. She recalls how she once sent her boss a bulleted list of ways to improve the company, at their request. But what she took to be a straightforward response was received as overly blunt, and even rude. </div><figure data-testid="Pullquote" class="pull-quote-module__container__1f2Dd article-body-module__element__5eCce"><blockquote class="pull-quote-module__citation__IKwYJ"><p data-testid="Heading" class="text-module__text__0GDob text-module__dark-grey__UFC18 text-module__bold__chuBM text-module__heading_5__0myM8 heading-module__base__p-zaD heading-module__heading_5_bold__46eB5 pull-quote-module__text__MEWbY">I know it’s a machine. But sometimes, honestly, it’s the most empathetic voice in my life.</p></blockquote><figcaption class="pull-quote-module__author__05EAq"><p data-testid="Body" class="text-module__text__0GDob text-module__dark-grey__UFC18 text-module__regular__qJJtA text-module__extra_small__8Buss body-module__base__o--Cl body-module__extra_small_body__Bfz20">Filmmaker Kate D’hotman</p></figcaption></figure><div data-testid="paragraph-6" class="text-module__text__0GDob text-module__dark-grey__UFC18 text-module__regular__qJJtA text-module__small__sph8i body-module__full_width__kCIGb body-module__small_body__gOmDf article-body-module__paragraph__Ts-yF">Now, she regularly runs things by ChatGPT, asking the chatbot to consider the tone and context of her conversations. Sometimes she’ll instruct it to take on the role of a psychologist or therapist, asking for help to navigate scenarios as sensitive as a misunderstanding with her best friend. She once uploaded months of messages between them, prompting the chatbot to help her see what she might have otherwise missed. Unlike humans, D’hotman says, the chatbot is positive and non-judgmental.</div><div data-testid="paragraph-7" class="text-module__text__0GDob text-module__dark-grey__UFC18 text-module__regular__qJJtA text-module__small__sph8i body-module__full_width__kCIGb body-module__small_body__gOmDf article-body-module__paragraph__Ts-yF">That’s a feeling other neurodivergent people can relate to. Sarah Rickwood, a senior project manager in the sales training industry, based in Kent, England, has ADHD and autism. Rickwood says she has ideas that run away with her and often loses people in conversations. “I don’t do myself justice,” she says, noting that ChatGPT has “allowed me to do a lot more with my brain.” With its help, she can put together emails and business cases more clearly.</div><div data-testid="element" class="article-body-module__element__5eCce article-body-module__full_bleed__rXIWT"></div><div data-testid="paragraph-8" class="text-module__text__0GDob text-module__dark-grey__UFC18 text-module__regular__qJJtA text-module__small__sph8i body-module__full_width__kCIGb body-module__small_body__gOmDf article-body-module__paragraph__Ts-yF">The use of AI-powered tools is surging. A January study conducted by Google and the polling firm Ipsos found that AI usage globally has jumped 48%, with excitement about the technology’s practical benefits now exceeding concerns over its potentially adverse effects. In February, OpenAI <a data-testid="Link" title="https://www.reuters.com/technology/artificial-intelligence/openais-weekly-active-users-surpass-400-million-2025-02-20/" referrerPolicy="no-referrer-when-downgrade" href="https://www.reuters.com/technology/artificial-intelligence/openais-weekly-active-users-surpass-400-million-2025-02-20/" rel="" class="text-module__text__0GDob text-module__inherit-color__PhuPF text-module__inherit-font__1P1hv text-module__inherit-size__EyiQW link-module__link__INqxZ link-module__underline_default__-okuC">told Reuters</a> that its weekly active users surpassed 400 million, of which at least 2 million are paying business users.</div><div data-testid="paragraph-9" class="text-module__text__0GDob text-module__dark-grey__UFC18 text-module__regular__qJJtA text-module__small__sph8i body-module__full_width__kCIGb body-module__small_body__gOmDf article-body-module__paragraph__Ts-yF">But for neurodivergent users, these aren’t just tools of convenience and some AI-powered chatbots are now being created with the neurodivergent community in mind.</div><div data-testid="paragraph-10" class="text-module__text__0GDob text-module__dark-grey__UFC18 text-module__regular__qJJtA text-module__small__sph8i body-module__full_width__kCIGb body-module__small_body__gOmDf article-body-module__paragraph__Ts-yF">Michael Daniel, an engineer and entrepreneur based in Newcastle, Australia, told Reuters that it wasn’t until his daughter was diagnosed with autism — and he received the same diagnosis himself — that he realised how much he had been masking his own neurodivergent traits. His desire to communicate more clearly with his neurotypical wife and loved ones inspired him to build Neurotranslator, an AI-powered personal assistant, which he credits with helping him fully understand and process interactions, as well as avoid misunderstandings. </div><div data-testid="paragraph-11" class="text-module__text__0GDob text-module__dark-grey__UFC18 text-module__regular__qJJtA text-module__small__sph8i body-module__full_width__kCIGb body-module__small_body__gOmDf article-body-module__paragraph__Ts-yF">“Wow … that’s a unique shirt,” he recalls saying about his wife’s outfit one day, without realising how his comment might be perceived. She asked him to run the comment through NeuroTranslator, which helped him recognise that, without a positive affirmation, remarks about a person’s appearance could come across as criticism. </div><div data-testid="element" class="article-body-module__element__5eCce article-body-module__full_bleed__rXIWT"></div><div data-testid="paragraph-12" class="text-module__text__0GDob text-module__dark-grey__UFC18 text-module__regular__qJJtA text-module__small__sph8i body-module__full_width__kCIGb body-module__small_body__gOmDf article-body-module__paragraph__Ts-yF">“The emotional baggage that [normally] comes along with those situations would just disappear within minutes,” he says of using the app. </div><div data-testid="paragraph-13" class="text-module__text__0GDob text-module__dark-grey__UFC18 text-module__regular__qJJtA text-module__small__sph8i body-module__full_width__kCIGb body-module__small_body__gOmDf article-body-module__paragraph__Ts-yF">Since its launch in September, Daniel says NeuroTranslator has attracted more than 200 paid subscribers. An earlier web version of the app, called Autistic Translator, amassed 500 monthly paid subscribers. </div><div data-testid="paragraph-14" class="text-module__text__0GDob text-module__dark-grey__UFC18 text-module__regular__qJJtA text-module__small__sph8i body-module__full_width__kCIGb body-module__small_body__gOmDf article-body-module__paragraph__Ts-yF">As transformative as this technology has become, some warn against becoming too dependent. The ability to get results on demand can be “very seductive,” says Larissa Suzuki, a London-based computer scientist and visiting NASA researcher who is herself neurodivergent. </div><div data-testid="PremiumArticleImage" class="premium-article-image-module__container__jOgXE premium-article-image-module__vertical__mHBmL article-body-module__element__5eCce article-body-module__img__n-qlE article-body-module__text_width__ZT9L0 vertical"><figure data-testid="image-1" dir="ltr" class="article-image-module__figure__DJ9zE"><div data-testid="Image" class="article-image-module__image__BInJs premium-article-image-module__image__zaPoY"><div class="styles-module__image-container__E0mCm styles-module__fill__Ft7kn styles-module__center_center__bzABO styles-module__apply-ratio__u0jXJ styles-module__transition__joucY" style="--aspect-ratio:0.9920283436669619"></div><noscript><img src="https://www.reuters.com/resizer/v2/C6TUYTOFBFDDDPMA3CGEKYKKKI.jpg?auth=b2fca559f1dff5e70f65a24a22cbf4d6a225a1f3aca220d006fafca1cb283728&width=1120&quality=80" width="1120" height="1129" alt="NeuroTranslator graphic" /></noscript></div><div data-testid="Body" class="text-module__text__0GDob text-module__dark-grey__UFC18 text-module__regular__qJJtA text-module__ultra_small__6-vhY body-module__full_width__kCIGb body-module__ultra_small_body__WelUC article-image-module__figcaption__S3axy article-body-module__figcaption__x2MkY premium-article-image-module__figcaption__FwQ0-"><span>A screenshot of the Neurotranslator app, provided by Michael Daniel.</span></div></figure></div><div data-testid="paragraph-15" class="text-module__text__0GDob text-module__dark-grey__UFC18 text-module__regular__qJJtA text-module__small__sph8i body-module__full_width__kCIGb body-module__small_body__gOmDf article-body-module__paragraph__Ts-yF">Overreliance could be harmful if it inhibits neurodivergent users’ ability to function without it, or if the technology itself becomes unreliable — as is already the case with many AI search-engine results, according to a recent study from the Columbia Journalism Review.<b> </b>“If AI starts screwing up things and getting things wrong,” Suzuki says, “people might give up on technology, and on themselves."</div><div data-testid="paragraph-16" class="text-module__text__0GDob text-module__dark-grey__UFC18 text-module__regular__qJJtA text-module__small__sph8i body-module__full_width__kCIGb body-module__small_body__gOmDf article-body-module__paragraph__Ts-yF">Baring your soul to an AI chatbot does carry risk, agrees Gianluca Mauro, an AI adviser and co-author of <i>Zero to AI</i>. “The objective [of AI models like ChatGPT] is to satisfy the user,” he says, raising questions about its willingness to offer critical advice. Unlike therapists, these tools aren’t bound by ethical codes or professional guidelines. If AI has the potential to become addictive, Mauro adds, regulation should follow.</div><div data-testid="element" class="article-body-module__element__5eCce article-body-module__full_bleed__rXIWT"></div><div data-testid="paragraph-17" class="text-module__text__0GDob text-module__dark-grey__UFC18 text-module__regular__qJJtA text-module__small__sph8i body-module__full_width__kCIGb body-module__small_body__gOmDf article-body-module__paragraph__Ts-yF">A recent study by Carnegie Mellon and Microsoft (which is a key investor in OpenAI) suggests that long-term overdependence on generative AI tools can undermine users’ critical-thinking skills and leave them ill-equipped to manage without it. “While AI can improve efficiency,” the researchers wrote, “it may also reduce critical engagement, particularly in routine or lower-stakes tasks in which users simply rely on AI.”</div><div data-testid="paragraph-18" class="text-module__text__0GDob text-module__dark-grey__UFC18 text-module__regular__qJJtA text-module__small__sph8i body-module__full_width__kCIGb body-module__small_body__gOmDf article-body-module__paragraph__Ts-yF">While Dr. Melanie Katzman, a clinical psychologist and expert in human behaviour, recognises the benefits of AI for neurodivergent people, she does see downsides, such as giving patients an excuse not to engage with others.</div><div data-testid="paragraph-19" class="text-module__text__0GDob text-module__dark-grey__UFC18 text-module__regular__qJJtA text-module__small__sph8i body-module__full_width__kCIGb body-module__small_body__gOmDf article-body-module__paragraph__Ts-yF">A therapist will push their patient to try different things outside of their comfort zone. "I think it's harder for your AI companion to push you," she says. </div><div data-testid="paragraph-20" class="text-module__text__0GDob text-module__dark-grey__UFC18 text-module__regular__qJJtA text-module__small__sph8i body-module__full_width__kCIGb body-module__small_body__gOmDf article-body-module__paragraph__Ts-yF">But for users who have come to rely on this technology, such fears are academic. </div><div data-testid="paragraph-21" class="text-module__text__0GDob text-module__dark-grey__UFC18 text-module__regular__qJJtA text-module__small__sph8i body-module__full_width__kCIGb body-module__small_body__gOmDf article-body-module__paragraph__Ts-yF">“A lot of us just end up kind of retreating from society,” warns D’hotman, who says that she barely left the house in the year following her autism diagnosis, feeling overwhelmed. Were she to give up using ChatGPT, she fears she would return to that traumatic period of isolation.</div><div data-testid="paragraph-22" class="text-module__text__0GDob text-module__dark-grey__UFC18 text-module__regular__qJJtA text-module__small__sph8i body-module__full_width__kCIGb body-module__small_body__gOmDf article-body-module__paragraph__Ts-yF">“As somebody who's struggled with a disability my whole life,” she says, “I need this.” </div><p data-testid="promo-box" class="text-module__text__0GDob text-module__dark-grey__UFC18 text-module__regular__qJJtA text-module__small__sph8i body-module__base__o--Cl body-module__small_body__gOmDf article-body-module__promo-box__hVl8h article-body-module__small-margin-bottom__-n0Co"> <!-- -->Sign up<!-- --> <!-- --> <a data-testid="Link" Richter","first_name":"Hani","last_name":"Richter","company":"Reuters","thumbnail":{"url":"https://cloudfront-us-east-2.images.arcpublishing.com/reuters/H24NV3AFCZCWPC463OG3JRYY7U.jpg","type":"image","resizer_url":"https://www.reuters.com/resizer/v2/https%3A%2F%2Fcloudfront-us-east-2.images.arcpublishing.com%2Freuters%2FH24NV3AFCZCWPC463OG3JRYY7U.jpg?auth=4dd3566d980534ddab2fb815cfdf9f08e04ca3d4f4dd0c88f6e42931b1e77167"},"social_links":[{"site":"email","url":"mailto:Hani.Richter@thomsonreuters.com"}],"byline":"Hani Richter","topic_url":"/authors/hani-richter/"}],"display_time":"2025-07-26T10:00:00Z","updated_time":"2025-07-26T10:00:00Z","excerpt":{"content":"For Cape Town-based filmmaker Kate D’hotman, connecting with movie audiences comes naturally. Far more daunting is speaking with others. “I’ve never understood how people [decipher] social cues,” the 40-year-old director of horror films says.","type":"paragraph"},"content_elements":[{"url":"https://cloudfront-us-east-2.images.arcpublishing.com/reuters/AILDGXEPLZHSDDFXQIV75A4KLA.jpg","caption":"Illustration by Karolis Strautniekas","type":"image","resizer_url":"https://www.reuters.com/resizer/v2/AILDGXEPLZHSDDFXQIV75A4KLA.jpg?auth=6608b87b8e5b9d604ef1c1eed3589deaf70f811536c1a26ed5cebeece11723f0","id":"AILDGXEPLZHSDDFXQIV75A4KLA","alt_text":"Neurodivergent illustration","width":1920,"height":1280,"subtitle":"Neurodivergent illustration","updated_at":"2025-07-22T20:44:42Z","layout_preferences":{"horizontal_alignment":"Full Column","image_orientation":"Horizontal","website":"render-settings"}},{"content":"For Cape Town-based filmmaker Kate D’hotman, connecting with movie audiences comes naturally. Far more daunting is speaking with others. “I’ve never understood how people [decipher] social cues,” the 40-year-old director of horror films says.","type":"paragraph"},{"content":"D’hotman has autism and attention-deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD), which can make relating to others exhausting and a challenge. However, since 2022, D’hotman has been a regular user of ChatGPT, the popular AI-powered chatbot from OpenAI, relying on it to overcome communication barriers at work and in her personal life. ","type":"paragraph"},{"content":"“I know it’s a machine,” she says. “But sometimes, honestly, it’s the most empathetic voice in my life.” ","type":"paragraph"},{"content":"Neurodivergent people — including those with autism, ADHD, dyslexia and other conditions — can experience the world differently from the neurotypical norm. Talking to a colleague, or even texting a friend, can entail misread signals, a misunderstood tone and unintended impressions.","type":"paragraph"},{"content":"AI-powered chatbots have emerged as an unlikely ally, helping people navigate social encounters with real-time guidance. Although this new technology is not without risks — in particular some worry about over-reliance — many neurodivergent users now see it as a lifeline.","type":"paragraph"},{"content":"How does it work in practice? For D’hotman, ChatGPT acts as an editor, translator and confidant. Before using the technology, she says communicating in neurotypical spaces was difficult. She recalls how she once sent her boss a bulleted list of ways to improve the company, at their request. But what she took to be a straightforward response was received as overly blunt, and even rude. ","type":"paragraph"},{"type":"pullquote","items":["I know it’s a machine. But sometimes, honestly, it’s the most empathetic voice in my life."],"citation_content":"Filmmaker Kate D’hotman","layout_preferences":{"horizontal_alignment":"Full Column","image_orientation":"Horizontal","website":"render-settings"}},{"content":"Now, she regularly runs things by ChatGPT, asking the chatbot to consider the tone and context of her conversations. Sometimes she’ll instruct it to take on the role of a psychologist or therapist, asking for help to navigate scenarios as sensitive as a misunderstanding with her best friend. She once uploaded months of messages between them, prompting the chatbot to help her see what she might have otherwise missed. Unlike humans, D’hotman says, the chatbot is positive and non-judgmental.","type":"paragraph"},{"content":"That’s a feeling other neurodivergent people can relate to. Sarah Rickwood, a senior project manager in the sales training industry, based in Kent, England, has ADHD and autism. Rickwood says she has ideas that run away with her and often loses people in conversations. “I don’t do myself justice,” she says, noting that ChatGPT has “allowed me to do a lot more with my brain.” With its help, she can put together emails and business cases more clearly.","type":"paragraph"},{"content":"The use of AI-powered tools is surging. A January study conducted by Google and the polling firm Ipsos found that AI usage globally has jumped 48%, with excitement about the technology’s practical benefits now exceeding concerns over its potentially adverse effects. In February, OpenAI <a href=\"https://www.reuters.com/technology/artificial-intelligence/openais-weekly-active-users-surpass-400-million-2025-02-20/\" rel=\"\" title=\"https://www.reuters.com/technology/artificial-intelligence/openais-weekly-active-users-surpass-400-million-2025-02-20/\">told Reuters</a> that its weekly active users surpassed 400 million, of which at least 2 million are paying business users.","type":"paragraph"},{"content":"But for neurodivergent users, these aren’t just tools of convenience and some AI-powered chatbots are now being created with the neurodivergent community in mind.","type":"paragraph"},{"content":"Michael Daniel, an engineer and entrepreneur based in Newcastle, Australia, told Reuters that it wasn’t until his daughter was diagnosed with autism — and he received the same diagnosis himself — that he realised how much he had been masking his own neurodivergent traits. His desire to communicate more clearly with his neurotypical wife and loved ones inspired him to build Neurotranslator, an AI-powered personal assistant, which he credits with helping him fully understand and process interactions, as well as avoid misunderstandings. ","type":"paragraph"},{"content":"“Wow … that’s a unique shirt,” he recalls saying about his wife’s outfit one day, without realising how his comment might be perceived. She asked him to run the comment through NeuroTranslator, which helped him recognise that, without a positive affirmation, remarks about a person’s appearance could come across as criticism. ","type":"paragraph"},{"content":"“The emotional baggage that [normally] comes along with those situations would just disappear within minutes,” he says of using the app. ","type":"paragraph"},{"content":"Since its launch in September, Daniel says NeuroTranslator has attracted more than 200 paid subscribers. An earlier web version of the app, called Autistic Translator, amassed 500 monthly paid subscribers. ","type":"paragraph"},{"content":"As transformative as this technology has become, some warn against becoming too dependent. The ability to get results on demand can be “very seductive,” says Larissa Suzuki, a London-based computer scientist and visiting NASA researcher who is herself neurodivergent. ","type":"paragraph"},{"url":"https://cloudfront-us-east-2.images.arcpublishing.com/reuters/C6TUYTOFBFDDDPMA3CGEKYKKKI.jpg","caption":"A screenshot of the Neurotranslator app, provided by Michael Daniel.","type":"image","resizer_url":"https://www.reuters.com/resizer/v2/C6TUYTOFBFDDDPMA3CGEKYKKKI.jpg?auth=b2fca559f1dff5e70f65a24a22cbf4d6a225a1f3aca220d006fafca1cb283728","id":"C6TUYTOFBFDDDPMA3CGEKYKKKI","alt_text":"NeuroTranslator graphic","width":1120,"height":1129,"subtitle":"NeuroTranslator graphic","updated_at":"2025-07-24T16:49:28Z","layout_preferences":{"horizontal_alignment":"Text Width","image_orientation":"Vertical","website":"render-settings"}},{"content":"Overreliance could be harmful if it inhibits neurodivergent users’ ability to function without it, or if the technology itself becomes unreliable — as is already the case with many AI search-engine results, according to a recent study from the Columbia Journalism Review.<b> </b>“If AI starts screwing up things and getting things wrong,” Suzuki says, “people might give up on technology, and on themselves.\"","type":"paragraph"},{"content":"Baring your soul to an AI chatbot does carry risk, agrees Gianluca Mauro, an AI adviser and co-author of <i>Zero to AI</i>. “The objective [of AI models like ChatGPT] is to satisfy the user,” he says, raising questions about its willingness to offer critical advice. Unlike therapists, these tools aren’t bound by ethical codes or professional guidelines. If AI has the potential to become addictive, Mauro adds, regulation should follow.","type":"paragraph"},{"content":"A recent study by Carnegie Mellon and Microsoft (which is a key investor in OpenAI) suggests that long-term overdependence on generative AI tools can undermine users’ critical-thinking skills and leave them ill-equipped to manage without it. “While AI can improve efficiency,” the researchers wrote, “it may also reduce critical engagement, particularly in routine or lower-stakes tasks in which users simply rely on AI.”","type":"paragraph"},{"content":"While Dr. Melanie Katzman, a clinical psychologist and expert in human behaviour, recognises the benefits of AI for neurodivergent people, she does see downsides, such as giving patients an excuse not to engage with others.","type":"paragraph"},{"content":"A therapist will push their patient to try different things outside of their comfort zone. \"I think it's harder for your AI companion to push you,\" she says. ","type":"paragraph"},{"content":"But for users who have come to rely on this technology, such fears are academic. ","type":"paragraph"},{"content":"“A lot of us just end up kind of retreating from society,” warns D’hotman, who says that she barely left the house in the year following her autism diagnosis, feeling overwhelmed. Were she to give up using ChatGPT, she fears she would return to that traumatic period of isolation.","type":"paragraph"},{"content":"“As somebody who's struggled with a disability my whole life,” she says, “I need this.” ","type":"paragraph"}],"promo_items":{"images":[{"url":"https://cloudfront-us-east-2.images.arcpublishing.com/reuters/AILDGXEPLZHSDDFXQIV75A4KLA.jpg","caption":"Illustration by readabilityObject.title: ‘It’s the most empathetic voice in my life’: How AI is transforming the lives of neurodivergent people
readabilityObject.content:
AI tools like ChatGPT are helping neurodivergent users communicate more clearly and confidently — though some experts warn that overreliance could come at a cost.

July 26, 202510:00 AM UTCUpdated July 26, 2025

For Cape Town-based filmmaker Kate D’hotman, connecting with movie audiences comes naturally. Far more daunting is speaking with others. “I’ve never understood how people [decipher] social cues,” the 40-year-old director of horror films says.

D’hotman has autism and attention-deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD), which can make relating to others exhausting and a challenge. However, since 2022, D’hotman has been a regular user of ChatGPT, the popular AI-powered chatbot from OpenAI, relying on it to overcome communication barriers at work and in her personal life.

“I know it’s a machine,” she says. “But sometimes, honestly, it’s the most empathetic voice in my life.”

Neurodivergent people — including those with autism, ADHD, dyslexia and other conditions — can experience the world differently from the neurotypical norm. Talking to a colleague, or even texting a friend, can entail misread signals, a misunderstood tone and unintended impressions.

AI-powered chatbots have emerged as an unlikely ally, helping people navigate social encounters with real-time guidance. Although this new technology is not without risks — in particular some worry about over-reliance — many neurodivergent users now see it as a lifeline.

How does it work in practice? For D’hotman, ChatGPT acts as an editor, translator and confidant. Before using the technology, she says communicating in neurotypical spaces was difficult. She recalls how she once sent her boss a bulleted list of ways to improve the company, at their request. But what she took to be a straightforward response was received as overly blunt, and even rude.

Now, she regularly runs things by ChatGPT, asking the chatbot to consider the tone and context of her conversations. Sometimes she’ll instruct it to take on the role of a psychologist or therapist, asking for help to navigate scenarios as sensitive as a misunderstanding with her best friend. She once uploaded months of messages between them, prompting the chatbot to help her see what she might have otherwise missed. Unlike humans, D’hotman says, the chatbot is positive and non-judgmental.

That’s a feeling other neurodivergent people can relate to. Sarah Rickwood, a senior project manager in the sales training industry, based in Kent, England, has ADHD and autism. Rickwood says she has ideas that run away with her and often loses people in conversations. “I don’t do myself justice,” she says, noting that ChatGPT has “allowed me to do a lot more with my brain.” With its help, she can put together emails and business cases more clearly.

The use of AI-powered tools is surging. A January study conducted by Google and the polling firm Ipsos found that AI usage globally has jumped 48%, with excitement about the technology’s practical benefits now exceeding concerns over its potentially adverse effects. In February, OpenAI told Reuters that its weekly active users surpassed 400 million, of which at least 2 million are paying business users.

But for neurodivergent users, these aren’t just tools of convenience and some AI-powered chatbots are now being created with the neurodivergent community in mind.

Michael Daniel, an engineer and entrepreneur based in Newcastle, Australia, told Reuters that it wasn’t until his daughter was diagnosed with autism — and he received the same diagnosis himself — that he realised how much he had been masking his own neurodivergent traits. His desire to communicate more clearly with his neurotypical wife and loved ones inspired him to build Neurotranslator, an AI-powered personal assistant, which he credits with helping him fully understand and process interactions, as well as avoid misunderstandings.

“Wow … that’s a unique shirt,” he recalls saying about his wife’s outfit one day, without realising how his comment might be perceived. She asked him to run the comment through NeuroTranslator, which helped him recognise that, without a positive affirmation, remarks about a person’s appearance could come across as criticism.

“The emotional baggage that [normally] comes along with those situations would just disappear within minutes,” he says of using the app.

Since its launch in September, Daniel says NeuroTranslator has attracted more than 200 paid subscribers. An earlier web version of the app, called Autistic Translator, amassed 500 monthly paid subscribers.

As transformative as this technology has become, some warn against becoming too dependent. The ability to get results on demand can be “very seductive,” says Larissa Suzuki, a London-based computer scientist and visiting NASA researcher who is herself neurodivergent.

Overreliance could be harmful if it inhibits neurodivergent users’ ability to function without it, or if the technology itself becomes unreliable — as is already the case with many AI search-engine results, according to a recent study from the Columbia Journalism Review. “If AI starts screwing up things and getting things wrong,” Suzuki says, “people might give up on technology, and on themselves."

Baring your soul to an AI chatbot does carry risk, agrees Gianluca Mauro, an AI adviser and co-author of Zero to AI. “The objective [of AI models like ChatGPT] is to satisfy the user,” he says, raising questions about its willingness to offer critical advice. Unlike therapists, these tools aren’t bound by ethical codes or professional guidelines. If AI has the potential to become addictive, Mauro adds, regulation should follow.

A recent study by Carnegie Mellon and Microsoft (which is a key investor in OpenAI) suggests that long-term overdependence on generative AI tools can undermine users’ critical-thinking skills and leave them ill-equipped to manage without it. “While AI can improve efficiency,” the researchers wrote, “it may also reduce critical engagement, particularly in routine or lower-stakes tasks in which users simply rely on AI.”

While Dr. Melanie Katzman, a clinical psychologist and expert in human behaviour, recognises the benefits of AI for neurodivergent people, she does see downsides, such as giving patients an excuse not to engage with others.

A therapist will push their patient to try different things outside of their comfort zone. "I think it's harder for your AI companion to push you," she says.

But for users who have come to rely on this technology, such fears are academic.

“A lot of us just end up kind of retreating from society,” warns D’hotman, who says that she barely left the house in the year following her autism diagnosis, feeling overwhelmed. Were she to give up using ChatGPT, she fears she would return to that traumatic period of isolation.

“As somebody who's struggled with a disability my whole life,” she says, “I need this.”

Sign up here.

Editing by Yasmeen Serhan and Sharon Singleton; Illustration by Karolis Strautniekas

Our Standards: The Thomson Reuters Trust Principles., opens new tab
